revisions.*:
'''Murali Coryell''' (born October 27, 1969) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[singer]]. Best known for performing live in small venues in [[New York State]], Coryell has also opened for [[George Thorogood]], [[Gregg Allman]], [[B.B. King]] and [[Wilson Pickett]]. While touring the United States, he uses local [[session musician]]s for his performances rather than traveling with a regular backing band.<ref name=projo>{{cite news|publisher=The Providence Journal|title=The wandering life suits Murali Coryell’s fresh musical style|date=June 26, 2008|url=http://www.projo.com/music/content/wk-pop26_06-26-08_V0ALCGG_v12.290e16e.html}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Murali Coryell was born to Julie Coryell and famed [[jazz fusion]] guitarist [[Larry Coryell]]. Murali's first interest was in playing the drums but, in a move he calls "inevitable", he switched to guitar at a young age.<ref name=stltoday>{{cite news|title=Murali Coryell making his own name as a guitarist|url=http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/entertainment/stories.nsf/music/story/40B2897EFF39A42D862574790078A7F0?OpenDocument|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|author=Perkins, Terry|date=July 3, 2008}}</ref>  Wanting to avoid competition with his father and his brother, [[Julian Coryell|Julian]], he perfected his own more mainstream style of soul and blues which draws comparisons to [[Jimi Hendrix]] and [[Carlos Santana]].<ref name=projo/><ref name=nyt>{{cite news|title=Born in Fame, Guitarist Finds His Own Career and His Own Sound|publisher=The New York Times|date=September 24, 2000|author=Rowe, Claudia|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CEFDE133BF937A1575AC0A9669C8B63}}</ref> Others have likened his style to the [[Memphis soul]] produced by labels such as [[Hi Records|Hi]] and [[Stax Records]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Washington Post|date=September 15, 1995|title=Coryell 'Wide Open' To Memphis Soul|author=Joyce, Mike}}</ref>

Coryell graduated from [[Staples High School (Connecticut)|Staples High School]] in [[Westport, Connecticut]], in 1987. He received a BA in music theory and composition from the [[SUNY New Paltz Music Department]] in 1992.

The title of his seond album ''2120'' was a reference to 2120 Michigan Avenue, the address of now-defunct R&B [[record label]] [[Chess Records]].<ref name=stltoday/> Coryell's maternal grandmother was the [[actress]] [[Carol Bruce]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Young Coryell chooses his own path|publisher=Bucks County Courier Times|author=Vineberg, Andy|date=October 25, 2007|url=http://www.phillyburbs.com/pb-dyn/news/81-10252007-1429654.html}}</ref>

In 2014, Coryell was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'DVD of the Year' category for ''Adventures Live''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref>

==Discography==
*''Eyes Wide Open'' (1995)
*''2120'' (1999)
*''The Coryells'' (2000) - with Larry and Julian Coryell
*''Strong as I Need to Be'' (2003)
*''The Future of Blues'' - [[Extended play|EP]] (2005)
*''The Same Damn Thing'' (2008)
*''Sugar Lips'' (2009)
